bug.short_desc: Kerberos reporting [122][Disk quota exceeded] when using KEYRING credential cache
bug.cf_doc_type: If docs needed, set a value

long_desc.thetext:
Description of problem:
Today I was able to log into my system properly using SSSD. However, I later locked my screen and then was unable to unlock it again. When I examined the logs, I saw that Kerberos was returning error code 122: "Disk quota exceeded".
When I changed the cache type in SSSD back to FILE caches in /tmp, I was finally able to unlock my screen. I updated the kernel today, so I'm of the opinion that something changed in the keyring that broke updating Kerberos keyring caches.
Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable): kernelkernel-4.5.4-300.fc24.x86_64 keyutils-1.5.9-8.fc24.x86_64
How reproducible: Unclear, needs more testing. (I'm not sure if I locked the screen earlier in the day or if it happened the first time).
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Log in using SSSD 2. Lock the screen. 3. Attempt to unlock the system.
Actual results: Screen wouldn't unlock.
Expected results: The correct password should unlock the screen.
Additional info:

I'm still seeing this problem with kernel-4.5.7-300.fc24.x86_64 and on a separate system from my original report.
The problem is definitely in the keyring, not SSSD because when this occurs, I can't do 'kinit username@REALM' successfully either.
kinit: Failed to store credentials: Disk quota exceeded while getting initial credentials
David, could you provide me some guidelines on what commands I can run to investigate the keyring? I'm not sure how to debug this any further, but it's a serious issue.

This bug turned out to actually be in gnome-online-accounts. Under certain rare conditions, there was a situation in which GOA would attempt to kinit, fail and then not remove the temporary entry in the keyring. As a result, the space would fill up after about 20 minutes.
It was fixed elsewhere (not tracked in Fedora), so I'm closing this bug.
